nodes.text: Economic decision making and market dynamics can be modeled using a quantum-inspired propensity framework that replaces classical utility with a probabilistic propensity function and leverages quantum probability, interference, entanglement, and quantum circuits to represent cognitive and market phenomena

Classical neoclassical economics assumes rational utility-maximisers drive prices to stable equilibrium, but empirical cognitive phenomena (e.g., preference reversal, order effects, disjunction effect) violate assumptions of fixed preferences and classical logic

Quantum probability, using a 2-norm and complex amplitudes, naturally models superposition, interference, and entanglement and is therefore well-suited to represent uncertainty and cognitive anomalies in decision making

Decision-makers are represented by a propensity function that gives the probability of transacting; this propensity can be expressed as the squared amplitude of an underlying quantum-like wave function
A simple two-qubit quantum circuit with rotation gates A and B and a C-NOT entangling gate is equivalent to sequential projections and can reproduce order effects and related cognitive phenomena

Quantum decision theory and quantum cognition frameworks have been used to explain phenomena classical utility models fail to capture, such as order effects, disjunction effect, preference reversal, and social entanglement in games

A given propensity function (e.g., a normal distribution over log-price) can be quantized by treating it as the probability distribution of a quantum wave function, enabling dynamics via entropic forces and quantum oscillator analogues

Entropic force for a propensity distribution P(x) is f(x)=gamma P'(x)/P(x); for a normal propensity this yields a linear restoring force F(x) = -k(x-mu) with k = gamma/sigma squared, interpretable as a spring-like tendency toward preferred price

The two-qubit circuit operation psi_f = Xc (A tensor B) psi_0 reproduces joint probabilities in sequential question scenarios and is algebraically equivalent to a one-qubit measurement sequence for arbitrary unitary A and B

The discussed quantum circuit can simulate specific phenomena: gate A as context and gate B as decision reproduces disjunction effect; gate A subjective and gate B objective reproduces preference reversal; circuit can model entangled strategic behavior in prisoner s dilemma

Mapping propensity to a quantum harmonic oscillator yields an associated mass m = hbar / (2 omega sigma squared) and an energy scale gamma = hbar omega squared over two, linking variance, inertia to change, and discrete energy levels to market statistical features

The information or energy required to change propensity between states x1 and x2 is Delta E = gamma log(P(x2)/P(x1)); for typical preference reversal factor of about 3 this energy is on the order of the base quantum oscillator energy hbar omega over two

The quantum propensity-entropic framework can be applied to model financial market statistics, option pricing, transaction dynamics, and threshold effects in choices (e.g., preference reversal threshold x2/x1 > 3 supported by cited empirical tests)

Advantages of the quantum propensity approach include consistent units for economic forces, incorporation of subjective and objective factors on equal footing, and the ability to capture interference, entanglement, and discrete-state effects absent in classical models

An acknowledged assumption and limitation is that quantifying social motivations and mental energy may be contested; the framework assumes propensity can be meaningfully modeled probabilistically even if inner motivations resist precise reduction
